title: What songs did the Clash cover, and what bands covered the Clash? - Quora

response.answer_text: I expect there have been numerous bands that have covered the Clash, but I can’t answer that part of the question. I can however answer the first part: the following is a quick list of songs the Clash covered on record between 1977 and 1980. Of course, it doesn’t count self covers like Jail Guitar Doors” or “1–2 Crush on You” or “Protex Blue” (the latter two songs from Mick Jones’ proto-Clash group the London SS, the latter a rewrite of one of Strummer’s 101′ers’ songs, with new lyrics by Jones. Police and Thieves: from their first album, a cover of a reggae song by Junior Murvin (co-written and produced by Lee “Scratch” Perry, who also produced the Clash’s third single “Complete Control.”Pressure Drop: another reggae/ska cover, originally by the Maytals, this one is one of their best covers — it was the B-side to “English Civil War” (I think)I Fought the Law: Originally a huge 1966 hit by Buddy Holly soundalike artist and general badass Bobby Fuller: it came as a bonus single in the USA to Give ’Em Enough Rope, it was released on the Cost of Living EP in 1979 in the UK.Brand New Cadillac: a cover of the 1959 rockabilly single by Vince Taylor, it did a good job cleansing the palette with some real primitive rock & roll after the more modern sounding “London Calling”Wrong ’Em Boyo: another reggae cover, originally done by Rulers, this song also quotes from the American folk standard “Stagger Lee". Not sure if the Rulers version does too or not.Revolution Rock: The Clash do reggae again, this one originally done by Danny Ray and the Revolutionaires.Amagideon Time: This was the B-side to “London Calling.” It is, surprise surprise, a reggae song. Originally done by Willie WilliamsTime Is Tight: a cover of the Booker T and the MGS song, releaesd on Black Market Clash.Every Little Bit Hurts: A cover of the classic Motown soul song popularized by Brenda Holloway.Junco Partner: a traditional song, one of the better songs on Sandinista!, marred a little by the odd productionLook Here: an jazzy album track off Sandinista!, this one was originally written by jazz artist Mose Allison.Police On My Back: this rockin’ ditty was originally done by reggae artist Eddy Grant, who had a giganto-hit a year or so later with “Electric Avenue.”

From memory, these ones Police and Thieves - originally by Junior Murvin English Civil War - a traditional English song Brand New Cadillac - Vince Taylor Wrong Em Boyo / Stagger Lee- don’t remember who did this originally, sorry Revolution Rock - Danny Ray and The Revolutionaries Look Here - Mose Allison Junco Partner - James Booker Police On My Back - Eddy Grant Pressure Drop - Toots and The Maytals Armagiddeon Time - Willie Williams I Fought The Law - Bobby Fuller There might be some b sides etc that I have forgotten that are also covers
